item.title: Learning From geohot's minikeyvalue Project
item.description: I first became aware of minikeyvalue while watching a recording of George’s programming livestream. This project was written in Python and the design was simple: an HTTP-based interface for storing, getting, and deleting arbitrary content. Many folks call this type of thing a “distributed key-value store”. The project was originally inspired by SeaweedFS but had the goal of being much, much simpler (ideally less than 1000 lines of code). The architecture of the program is straightforward: a single “index server” distributes and organizes data between any number of “volume servers”.
